review_title: Our house is a tiny little model!
one_reviews_text:
I found our neighborhood and was hovering in the air above our house. I was trying to make out more detail, but no matter which buttons I tried I couldn't make my point-of-view get any closer to the ground. In frustration I leaned forward a bit, and realized that I was getting closer to the ground. Wondering what would happen, I got down on my hands and knees to peer at our house and was absolutely dumbfounded to find that it was a perfect tiny little model! I could see our little umbrella in the backyard, and could put my head on the ground to look under the front porch overhang to see our front door. This was a staggering and very moving experience ... I hadn't expected anything more than tiny little blotches for each house. Wow!

When my wife came home I had setup Google Earth VR to be above our neighborhood then put the headset on her and asked her to find our house. She followed the streets around and could pinpoint it. I asked her if she could see our backyard. No, no, she couldn't see that much detail. I told her to get closer. "What do you mean?" she said. "How would I do that?" I told her to get down on her hands and knees. "What? Really?" But she did ... and then, "Hey! That's my car in the driveway!

I haven't tried to figure out if there are ways of pointing at something and finding out details, or getting into Street View mode, but I'm excited to find out what else this app can do!

This app is the Eighth Wonder of the World as far as I’m concerned.  Much different from the Wander app available on the Go and Quest.  In this app, you're in a 3D world where you can fly around like Superman, checking out all sorts of famous places, natural wonders, old neighborhoods, vacation locales - you name it.  Fly in for a close view, or fly up for a big picture view.  All in 3D.  Trust me, you will spend HOURS using this.  Zoom in really close, bring your left hand up to your face, and you are immediately transported into Google Street View.  Otherwise, everything is rendered in a shockingly cool computerized 3D that makes it seem like you’re looking at an intricately constructed model of the locale you’re viewing.  

Want to see how your home looks from a height of a few hundred feet up (or a few thousand)?  Just fly up and check it out.  Want to zoom over the Colorado River as it passes through the Grand Canyon, with the canyon walls towering above you - go ahead and do it, nobody's stopping you.  Or fly down between city buildings and you’ll see a pristine version of reality, complete with miniature models of street signs, billboard advertisements, traffic lights, and even cracks in the street concrete.  Honestly, sometimes it’s a disappointment to switch from the rendered 3D environment over to the real world Street View perspective.  

Others have complained that the app can be improved in this way or that, and I’m sure there’s room to improve on plenty of things, but let’s be honest - this app is flat out amazing.

review_title: The Power of Google Earth VR
one_reviews_text:
Video review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gnCh2kCLlSA

Lots of people say VR needs a killer app, but what if I told you there was one? I'm talking about Google Earth VR. Now, I know what you're thinking, Google Earth is VR's killer app? While the desktop version is pretty cool, it doesn't blow me away like the VR version. In virtual reality, it will make your jaw drop.

Google Earth VR still uses the desktop version's satellite imagery, but in VR, you'll feel like you're flying around the world. Much of the planet is rendered in 3D using photogrammetry, which helps induce a sense of "presence," or the feeling like you're really there. If you’ve never used the desktop version, you’d think Google Earth was built from the ground up for VR. I personally feel a bit like Superman as I soar through the sky and observe the vast expanse of the Milky Way around me. Enabling the app’s human-scale mode allows you to zip down into the nooks and crannies below. 

Google Earth VR excels at allowing you to see familiar places in a new light. People have also inadvertently stumbled across more efficient routes getting home using the app. 

It’s not perfect, though, and it’s definitely no replacement for actually visiting real-world locations. Its biggest flaw is that when you get really low into the streets, it starts to look a bit, well, post-apocalyptic. This is because Google doesn’t have enough low-level data from its satellite imagery. There are also some places, like Iceland and Columbia, that aren’t completely rendered in 3D. You end up with a 3D-mapped topology of the landscape, without any of the buildings or city infrastructure. 

But when Google Earth VR works, it soars. One aspect of the app that probably wasn't originally intended was its power to induce a tremendous sense of nostalgia. In a way, Google Earth VR is a time machine. It captures a snapshot of the world frozen in a moment. Waves on the ocean and cars on the road appear in a state of suspended animation.

In this, you get a street view, but you must leave street view in order to get to the next part. It's kind of a pain if you want to travel on the road. Apart from that it's brilliant.

When I saw Google Earth had a VR version, I thought : "Ok, cool, but that's certainly something I'll try five minutes and then leave  behind...". So, I didn't bother to download it.
Then I saw the marks and the critics here on the Oculus Store. "Wow, is it really that awesome? Better check it out then!", I thought.

So, I tried it... "Oh.MY.God! How could I not try this earlier?". I was amazed!

So, this may seem strange, but yeah, Google Earth is definitely among the BEST VR experiences you can get!

This software works just like the normal one : you travel through the 3D model of the world. Except it's in VR : your "character" can be put at human scale, then you can get besides the monuments of the world and feel it almost like you were really there!

The movements are awesome : you fly like Superman. Either you stay on the ground and feel the place like you were driving an invisible car, or you fly up in the air. You can even switch between two "modes" : either you're ON Earth and fly all around, or you're IN SPACE and make the Earth turn. This moment when you switch from one mode to another... really, I can't express how awesome that was. Like you suddenly lose (or regain) gravity. This is something to live. Definitely.

Besides, StreetView really shows its full potential in VR. I mean, like it was MADE for it.
StreetView allows you to see 360 photos of many places. But on a flatscreen, well... you probably know what this does : sure that's cool, but not really immersive as you move around with the mouse. In VR, the photo is AROUND YOU, and it really gives the sensation that you are there!

Now, the quality of the models and the pictures vary from one place to another. That's because of the nature of this project : it never stops improving.

So, if you hesitate : don't worry, try it out! BUT don't forget to change a bit the settings, to have human size.

Anyway, I can't wait for Google to implement other planets and satellites in this!
